Hi Colin-

I am surprised to hear that you would favor doubling the input space over
having the NN just figure out that a 0 or a -1 should be ignored. I don't
have any experience in this realm, but I guess I always assumed that the
more inputs, the harder the problem.

Shouldn't it be rather easy for neural nets to ignore 0s? I mean, a 0 input
multiplied by any link value is 0..so it has no effect on the neuron it is
connected to. Right?

Can you expand on your intuitions behind thinking that doubling the input
space is the best way to go?

Christian- 
Are you sure that your problem works ok even without this missing data
problem? Is it a problem that you could try to run just on the subset of
data that have no missing holes, just to see if it can do the task? This is
akin to trying a simple version of the problem to see if it works...in order
to rule out that your problem is not more upstream.




Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

jclune@...




> From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>

> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: Re: [neat] unassigned input values for Neural Net
> 
> Hi Christain,
> 
> I would do as you suggested and double up the number of input neurons.
> If however it's always the same 50% that have no input, and they are
> missing the input at the same time then you could just have one input
> that indciates that that group of input data is missing.
> 
> Colin
